answers.text:
Nematullah - here are some other ideas:
ICMA's Center for Sustainable Commuities is implementing the SunShot initiative - there are lots of case studies and podcasts of communities of different sizes tackling different elements of renewable energy adoption. The “resource” section would also be worth exploring.  Check out  http://icma.org/en/results/sustainable_communities/projects/solar and
http://energy.gov/eere/sunshot/sunshot-initiative and 
Also check out our series on Asset Based Economic Development and this article highlights ideas and resources related to renewable energy - waste to energy - http://icma.org/en/international/resources/insights/Article/103998/AssetBased_Economic_Development_Renewable_Energy_and_Local_Resources 
Also from the International Energy Agency - http://www.iea.org/techinitiatives/renewableenergy/renewableenergytechnologydeployment/?utm_content=bufferaa3d5&utm_medium=social&utm_source=linkedin.com&utm_campaign=buffer
Hope this helps

Hi Nematullah, 
Thank you for asking such an interesting question! Hopefully another international member will be able to add more to the discussion later. I was able to find some documents that discuss the implementation of renewable energies and what to think about in terms of behavior change and financially to help make renewable energies a reality. While these studies are based in the US I think the basic principles should be transferable. 
-Property Assessed Clean Energy Bonds https://icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/301610
-Asset Based Economic Development: Renewable Energy and Local Resources http://icma.org/en/international/resources/insights/Article/103998/AssetBased_Economic_Development_Renewable_Energy_and_Local_Resources
Best, 
Robin Saywitz

author: Nematullah Haidari
text:
According to Energy Directorate of Ministry of Energy & Water, Afghanistan has the potential to produce about 1,408 million cubic meters (MCM) of biogas annually, equivalent to about 32 trillion Btu which fulfills today’s energy need of Afghanistan. The electrical energy from the combustible portion of the Municipal Solid Waste in Afghanistan’s major urban areas, using thermo-chemical conversion, is estimated at 134 GWh per year. There is also 158,000 MW Wind potential i.e. 5 MW/Km2 in the country and great potential for solar power i.e. 300 Sunny Days, average 6.5 kWh/m2 per day solar radiation. 
What are some experiences of other developing countries in harnessing of renewable energy?
Keeping that explanation in mind, what would be some economically viable and technically achievable strategies and techniques that can be applied in Afghanistan?
title: Harnessing Renwable Energies
